question = r"""""".strip().lower().split(',') # for Rule 1-6, 8-9

rule = r"""""".strip().lower()

secret_q, sAnswers, sRule = ([] for i in range(3))
a, b, c, aa = 0, 0, 0, 0

for i, w in enumerate(question):
    i = i+1
    for all in w:
        if all==' and':
            if w==question[-1]:
                a += w[w.index('and')+4:-1]
            else:
                a = w[w.index('and')+4:-1]
        elif all==' ' and w[-1]=='and':
            a += ' ' + w[-3]
        elif all in ' aaboveaboutabeyan#face  forhalf  hishowonherehomylocomotornnepprhowtheysumwanwhatwith'.split():
            a += all + ' ' + w[w.index(all)+len(all)+1:-1]
        elif all == 'over':
            if w[-1] != 'and':
                a += ' before '\
                     + w[:w.index('over')] + '\
'
            else:
                a += ' before '+'\nk '.join(w[:w.index('over')].split())
        else:
            raise NotImplementedError
        if w[-1]=='with':
            sRule += a
            secret_q.append(w)
            aa += 1
            b, c = a.split()
            q = b + ' ' + c
            secret_list, rule_ans = run_rule_1(q, answers[aa-1])
            sRule += q+' = '+str(secret_list)
            break
secret_q = ' '.join(secret_q)
sAnswers += ' = ' + ', '.join(answers)

Unfortunately, I am taking a break for a few weeks. This is about completion, not just 'term list' for all letters. I will solve it again as soon it opens for new question.


## Post Mortem

OK, I thought I had a solution/answer to this puzzle but re-read it with fresh eyes (fresh brain) after a few days, and still couldn't understand it.
In order to understand it, you take the puzzle but discard a lot of information in your brain to facilitate simplifying the problem. This kind of question doesn't really have one answer or solution, simply because it can be broken down into smaller parts of the problem.
It can be useful to simplify by removing hanging words, for example, 'an answer' at the end of the question. However, taking the middle two letters of the question (a n) is just wordplay.
There is an answer to the puzzle, though it does not have to be strictly ordered.
I am not sure if this puzzle has ever had one clear answer. Perhaps, because take the first X letters in the puzzle? hasn't quite clarified the puzzle as I would like.
An algorithm for taking the first X numbers and creating XXX words from those letters may be helpful. I believe jafe has answered in as simple as form, but lets see if others can add something to the original puzzle.

## 2nd Update

I think I now have an answer that passes the puzzles rules/requirements as a TS code within the <span> of each set of 5 words. I had previously failed to get the first set of 5 words to pass the second test within the 'AA..ABC*' requirement. I had also tried the first and last letters of each word, but this has a limitation in that it always returns the first and last letters of each word.

## SOLUTION
After the last update I thought I created an algorithm that passed some of the requirements but was previously rejected.

Run Dali's code with 55 in Custom Test! It still passes this test. And remember, this algorithm follows the rules for the 15x15 question exactly;

Take the first five words
Order them in reverse and display all answers
Shown down then up and then optionally with an extra row of * characters that contains the letters missing from each of the first five words
The words are separated by spaces. I do not recall if this is required or not, but leaving that off would make it a lot harder
No output will be generated once the puzzle is solved

I'm going to sleep on this to see if any changes occur.

def fine_grain_answer_format(predictions, knowledge_graph):
    """Return a question answering response formatted for fine grain knowledge graphs.

    Arg:
        predictions: A list of strings from mBERT that are scored from highest to lowest.
        knowledge_graph: The knowledge graph used to answer the questions.
    Returns:
        A list of three lists containing question ids, answer ids, and prediction ids for the given knowledge graph.
        For many graphs, only two lists will be present.
        Either the question ids or prediction ids will be empty.
    Raises:
        ValueError: If the format of the arg `predictions` is incorrect.
    """
    question_ids = []
    answer_ids = []
    prediction_ids = []
    for question, target, prediction in predictions:
        tokens = question.split()
        for x in prediction.split():
            if len(x) > 3:
                merge_mapping = []
                if knowledge_graph[target][x.upper()] != []:
                    merge_mapping.append(target.upper())
                merge_mapping += knowledge_graph[x.upper()]
                question_ids.append(question)
                answer_ids.append(target)
                prediction_ids.append(merge_mapping)
                break
    return [
        question_ids,
        answer_ids,
        prediction_ids,
    ]

primitiveinputs = 'primitiveinputs.txt'
outputs = 'outputinputs.txt'
queries = 'prelimanswers.txt'
counter = 'counter.txt'

solution_counter = 0
answer_counter = 0

rule_drawer = []

with open(primitiveinputs, 'r') as p:
    for line in p:
        if line[0] == '!':
            rule_drawer.append(line[1:].rstrip())
            pass
        pass

gen = subprocess.Popen(['python','genchem.py','--filename','gpevolutions.csv','--groupid','gpepatterns','--threshold','100','--reactions', 'genchem/rulegen.py'], stdout=subprocess.PIPE)

f = open(outputs, 'w')

for i in range(200):
    gen_output = gen.stdout.readline()
    gen_output = gen_output.replace("'",'"').lower()

    for thing in [' from ', ' using']:
        gen_output = gen_output.replace(thing,'')

    gen_output = gen_output.replace('[[','').replace(']]','').replace(',;',',')
    gen_output = gen_output.split(',')

    only_alpha = []
    for thing in gen_output:
        only_alpha.append(''.join([x for x in thing if not x.isdigit()]))

    answer = ''
    if gen_output != ['root']:
        answer_counter += 1

        for test in range(1, 1000):

            head_count = 0

            for rule in rule_drawer:
                head = find_head(rule, only_alpha[0])

                if rule.find(test) != -1:
                    head += find_head(rule, only_alpha[test])

                if len(head) > 0:
                    head_count += 1

            if head_count == 0:
                answer += test
            else:
                break

        f.write('[' + answer + ']\n')
    else:
        f.write('\n')

    f.write(gen_output[0] + ': [' + only_alpha[0] + ']\n')
    for i in range(1,len(gen_output)):
        if only_alpha[i] != 'None':
            f.write(gen_output[i] + ': [' + only_alpha[i] + ']\n')
        else:
            f.write(gen_output[i] + ': [\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)]')
    f.write('\n\n')

    progress = str(round(i/200*100)) + '%'
    progress_counter = str(int(i/200*1200))

    if str(round((i//200)*100,1)) < format(100, '.1f'):
        f.write('\n')
        f.write('#' * int(format(100 - (round(i/200*100) - 1), '.1f')))
        f.write(' -' + ' ' * (int(format(100 - (round(i/200*100) - 1), '.1f')) // 2) + '>')

f.write(str(answer_counter))
f.close()

### Syntactic Summary

Named terms can be used in an English questions.
The named terms are beginning, Ending, Rearrange,
Questions and Answers.
Answer has six parts, the last part is called
stricken (or original). In fact this helps in giving feedback.
Alphabet is combined with named terms, in a required form
(that's why generators should be banned). Characters are combined
in an expanded form, including adding letters showwhatinside A=ABC

The following automatic text-variable is adopted -{text}-. For a better
understanding, look at the template sections, marked with:
# Nested Template Sections

### Tool Template

Your task is to apply this rule to the provided question.
Pass an English sentence, i.e. command, not a list of letters
or a symbol, that should associated to the code word. Since you don't like this kind of answers through, another helpful tool is a comment
line at the begging. Text.E reset the text-variable -{text}-.
Example Answer format: letting user choose between resurgence and chorl with
auto-comment that_ resurges by default, to_ ensure cleaner_ output; I should
not have plowed through this, Q: [{#3pl1034-Q1_V1,Q2_V1,Q3}]; A: [{#plede,zyleR1korhtq1,tame resurgence,Korht UBOAZL1P}].
There are several tools for depending (or changing of) letters and variables.
The original, with all parts described: -{resurgence,chorl,auto}-_ -{Eric,Patrick,Homer}-.


## 2018/09/23 (Unordered List)

• This syntax:
  open a list, terminating with a or a comma
• [#2pl1124-Q1H-C2,#2pl1124-Q2H-C1,#2pl1124-Q3M-C2]
• shuld give the following solution:
  + [{#bleedy66-Q12I,#able66-Q12M,#bleedy66-Q12J},#bleedy66,#able66-J-C1C6,#bleedy66-J-C1C6]
+ [{#bleedy66-J1,#bleedy66-J2,#bleedy66-J3},#bleedy66-D-C1C6,#bleedy66-I-C1C6,#bleedy66-M-C1C6]
• you notice that commas after a list doesn't affect output

### Syntactic Supplement

Multi-word double code words can be supplied in the text, separated by
space. We use {{x}} as a word separator. For example,
"I am already done {{with}} this {{kind of answers}}" can be used in the
template entry.
Another feature is lists of captures. By default, it's unbolded shown as
a bullet. However, it's blue printed for a particular query (-{Q3T}
requested II).

All templates consist of:
• 2: arbitrary match
• 3: unused but existing arrow
• 4_N: unused vowel or consonant but existing more than once
• I.e.: I, L and U appear in all templates
• 1. single wildcard, four construction steps (ascn bass rst bcha)
• 2. letter, wildcard in any place and single wildcard in any place, move to begin and loop
• 3. construction apply for all question words if done only one
• 4 redirection via a single wildcard
• 5: second question word
• 6: wildcard in any position
• 11. join next two constructs

#### Special Conditions

• SELECT joins two constructs with consecutive single wildcards found:
  cons(ab/sCDe) - sta(aeh/bC)
  trans(abCcd/e) - cons(bcd/iC/S%)
• MULTI-CONDITIONS are when at least par substitutions are possible:
  cons(abcd/abC/Sd) - sta(abD/aCe)
  trans(Bcd/efA) - ... - sta(ae)/sta(dC)

and now the last Q12 is set to variable event_, and chonging  altk_wkdh_ for M1mo^0mta^

### Name

text is /texthasn/ which describes video conferencing
and M1 gives you a choice of translation between matches. Keep variables in
mind.

# Commands

This template solves multiple named questions. Inside the standard answer a
bracket-enclosed list of collapsible, numbered, algorithmically selected
expressions is required. The symbol '-{^}' indicates a special marker not
seen elsewhere, equal to an arc-filled triangle from Geometry.

Obviously, nested algorithms can increase the answer and themselves use the
named terms. Each occurrence requires obviously only / run in-line copy and
paste / syntax.

# Examples

The following example works with the first predicate flag '-{P1}' selected
by a question number. Comparing -{hzrngreigrnqwrtitergtdgrtm1} with the
first named predicate '-{P1}', the last word '-{^}' becomes [] and the outer
tridiagonal, enclosed by a set of square comers ('{'/'}'). When using

"""

    This is a post-order depth-first-search that exhaustive matches all paths. Even if no path is found it will take the computer to the leaf node.
    The check for the "valid" has multiple steps to deal with mutil-character chars like "oing" and "gooey". Each of these steps is required and this includes checking that the word is not multiple letters from startWord. To check for belonging.

"""
def postOrderDFS(thisWord, nextWord, lastLetter, validChars, charsAltered, results, startWord, endWord):
    if thisWord == endWord:
        yield [[charsAltered]]
        return

    for i, onto in enumerate(nextWord):
        # Check to see if nextWord[i] is in validChars
        if nextWord[i] not in validChars:
            # if nextWord[i] is not validchar then return to the last valid character found.
            continue
        # If this word is less than lastLetter
        # for alpha reserved words like [I,0,O,5, openParen in ACSL lists
        if thisWord < lastLetter:
            continue
        for v in range(ord("a"), ord("z") + 1):
            # Check if onto is orth
            orth = chr(v)
            # if Orth is not equal to onto continue
            if orth != onto:
                continue
            # create a copy of all characters between thisWord and the lastLetter Istead of removing from reference var every time
            freshWord = thisWord[:i] + orth + thisWord[i + 1:]
            # if the word is not found in the validChar list the continue
            if not freshWord in validChars.values():
                continue

            # Yo'u might be asking why not use the in statement. this is because of issue with multi character chears which are valid to the DSL
            # eg fire - fireplace, or clean - clear, or clumsy - alias
            # after this they become valid characters to change

            # if this is the last letter then this word can no longer be the start of the path
            # or if the charsAltered is > 0 then there has at least one char changed besides the last pass
            # if startWord == freshWord:
            #     continue

            # now have to check if the char is already changed and the last Ort is not an ACSL char in the DSL
            # Then foreide the char conflict
            if charsAltered > 0:
                # Count the number of chars left that are not AndX between startWord and freshWord
                same = 0
                if len(startWord) == len(freshWord):
                    for j, k in zip(startWord, freshWord):
                        if j == k:
                            same += 1
                # If the chars left are not equal to the same count of letters left then we forejie the entire path
                if len(startWord) - same != len(freshWord) - same:
                    continue
                # then recurse for nextWord
                for v in postOrderDFS(freshWord, endWord, orth, validChars, charsAltered, results, startWord, endWord):
                    yield v
            # don't alter char count if this character does not alter the path lengths so charsaltered will never be equal to zero
            else:
                for v in postOrderDFS(freshWord, endWord, orth, validChars, charsAltered + 1, results, startWord, endWord):
                    yield v

def solve_puzzle(question):
    """Simple solver using defaultdicts"""
    question_dict = defaultdict(int)
    total_dict = defaultdict(int)

    # Build the problem
    question = [[(int(x) if x.isdigit() else x) for x in line.split()] for line in question.split('\n')]

    # Build the dicts for each line
    for i, line in enumerate(question):
        total_dict[i] = question[i][-1]
        for j, val in enumerate(line):
            if val != 'X':
                question_dict[j, i] = val

    # Solve the puzzle
    solved = False
    while not solved:
        total = sum(question_dict.values())

        # Break if the problem is solved
        if total == sum(total_dict.values()):
            solved = True
            break

        # Solve for X's in rows
        for i, row in enumerate(question):
            if total_dict[i] > total:
                diff = total_dict[i] - total
                cols = [(x,i) for x in range(len(row)) if question_dict[x,i] == 'X']
                k,v = min([(row[x], abs(row[x]-diff))
                           for j,x in cols], key=lambda y:y[1])
                if k != 'X':
                    total_dict[i] = total_dict[i] - k + v
                    question_dict[cols[question[i].index(k)]
                                  ] = question[i][cols[question[i].index(k)]
                                                  ]

        # Solve for X's in columns
        for j, col in enumerate(list(zip(*question))):
            if total_dict[j] > total:
                diff = total_dict[j] - total
                row = [(x,j) for x in range(len(col)) if question_dict[x,j] == 'X']
                k,v = min([(col[x], abs(col[x]-diff))
                           for j,x in row], key=lambda y:y[1])
                if k != 'X':
                    total_dict[j] = total_dict[j] - k + v
                    question_dict[row[col.index(k)][0]
                                  ] = question[row[col.index(k)][0]].pop(-1)

    # return the solutions, sorted by their answers
    solved = list(sorted(question_dict.items(), key=lambda x:x[1]))
    solution = list(zip(*(list(zip(*solved))[1])))

    return solution

if __name__ == '__main__':
    q = """2  7  6  X  X  5  X

    print(f'[{",".join(out[0:-1])},{out[-1]}]')

1.The puzzle is played on an n x n grid, filling in the numbers so that each row and column contains all the numbers from 1 to n without repetition.
2.There are inequality signs (greater than ">" or less than "<") between certain squares in the grid. These inequality signs indicate the numerical relationship between two neighboring grids. For example, if a grid has a ">" sign above it, then the number of that grid must be greater than the number of the grid above it.
3.Some grids will give pre-filled numbers as hints.
4.The questions are given as matrices and are accompanied by inequality constraints below in the form (row i, column j) > (row x, column y)

title: Vector puzzles
rule_content:
1.The game is played on an n*n grid containing numbered and blank squares.
2.Arrows are drawn by players.
3.Each numbered square emits an arrow, which can extend up, down, left or right.
4.The number of blank squares covered by arrows must equal the number on the black square.
5.Arrows cannot pass through or cross other arrows.
6.Each blank square must be covered by at least one arrow.
7.The question is given by a matrix of blank squares filled with X. The player should replace these regions with the four arrows ↓ ↑ → ← and output the drawn matrix.

import itertools
from itertools import product

def check_rule(Q):
  answer = []
  n = len(Q)
  for i in range(n):  # iterate across rows
    if ' '.join(Q[i]) == ' ':  # empty row
      continue
    else:
      for j in range(n):  # iterate across columns
        if (" " in (" ".join(Q[i])[j:j+2])):
            answer.append((i+1,j+1))
  if len(answer) < 2*(n//2):
    return False
  if 'Z' in Q:
    r1, c1 = '', ''
    for i in range(len(Q[Q.index('Z')])):
      if Q[0][i] != Q[Q.index('Z')][i]:
        r1 += Q[0][i]
        c1 += Q[Q.index('Z')][i]
      else:
        pass
    return r1 == c1

            else:

    else:

                if Q[i+1] != " ":

                    index += 1

                else:

                  index += 1
                  break
                index = i
        else:
          ch.append(Q[i])
          break
      Q = ch[index:]

def find_words(r1: str, r2: str) -> dict:
  words = list()
  words.append(r1)
  words.append(r2)

  while "" in words[len(words) - 1]: words[len(words) - 1] = words[len(words) - 1].replace("", " ")

  words[0] = list(words[0].split(" "))
  words[1] = list(words[1].split(" "))
  word = list()

  if lexical_distance(words[0][0], words[1][0]) == 0 or lexical_distance(words[0][len(words[0]) - 1], words[1][len(words[1]) - 1]) == 0:
    word = words[len(words) - 1][len(words[len(words) - 1]) - 1] + words[len(words) - 1][len(words[len(words) - 1]) - 2] if len(
      words[len(words) - 1]) >= 2 else words[len(words) - 1][len(words[len(words) - 1]) - 1]
  elif len(words[0]) == 1:
    r = ''.join(words[len(words) - 2])
    r += ''.join(words[len(words) - 1])
    word = r
    letters_to_insert_in_choosen_matrix(words, word)
  if len(words[1]) == 0 or len(words[1]) == 1 or len(words[1]) == len(words[len(words) - 1]):
    if len(words[1]) == 1:
      r = ''.join(words[0])
      r += ''.join(words[len(words) - 1])
      word = r
      letters_to_insert_in_choosen_matrix(words, word)
    else:
      r = ''.join(words[len(words) - 1])
      r += ''.join(words[len(words) - 2])
      word = r
      letters_to_insert_in_choosen_matrix(words, word)

  if len(words[0]) > 2 or len(words[1]) >= 2: return letters_to_insert_in_choosen_matrix(words, word)
  return []

def letters_to_insert_in_choosen_matrix(words: list, word: str) -> dict:
  matrix = list()

  if len(words[1]) == 2 or len(words[len(words) - 1]) == 2:
    index = 1
    for i in range(0, len(word)):
      letters[words[len(words) - 1][index]][words[index - 1][i]] = word[i]
      int_for_mapping_index.append([i, index])
      if (index + 1) % len(words[index]) != 0 or i == (len(word) - 1): index += 1

  else:
    if len(words) == 3:
      index_else = 2 if len(words[2]) == 2 else 1

      if len(words[index_else]) > 1:
        for i in range(0, len(word)):
          in_words_matrix[0][i] = ''.join(str(e)) if i < index_else - 1 else ''
          letters[words[len(words) - 1][i]][words[index_else - 1][i]] = word[i]
          int_for_mapping_index.append([i, i + index_else])
          if i == (len(word) - 1) and i % len(words[index_else]) != 0:
            in_words_matrix[0][i + 1] = ''.join(str(e))

      else:
        for i in range(0, len(word)):
          in_words_matrix[0][i] = ''.join(str(e))
          letters[words[len(words) - 1][i]][''.join(str(e))] = word[i]
          int_for_mapping_index.append([i, words[index_else][0] + i])
          if i == (len(word) - 1) and i % len(words[index_else]) != 0:
            in_words_matrix[0][i + 1] = ''

  return {"matrix": matrix, "chars": letters, "char_number_mapping": int_for_mapping_index, "in_words_matrix":in_words_matrix}

def lexical_distance(smaller_word: str, bigger_word: str) -> int:
  smaller_len = len(smaller_word)
  bigger_len = len(bigger_word)
  matrix = np.zeros((smaller_len + 1, bigger_len + 1))

  for i in range(smaller_len):
    matrix[i + 1][0] = i + 1
  for i in range(bigger_len):
    matrix[0][i + 1] = i + 1

  for i in range(smaller_len):
    for j in range(bigger_len):
      match = 1
      if smaller_word[i] == bigger_word[j]: match = 0
      matrix[i + 1][j + 1] = min(matrix[i + 1][j] + 1, matrix[i][j + 1] + 1, matrix[i][j] + match)
      matrix[i + 1][j + 1] = int(matrix[i + 1][j + 1]) if matrix[i + 1][j + 1] == 0 else matrix[i + 1][j + 1]

  return matrix[smaller_len][bigger_len]

# Rules:



• A move is either adding/removing a 'Y' or swapping indices 1 and 2.
• The move that takes us from one word to the next is the move that is also in that direction in the sentence SPERN PALANT.

• You can use one or two quotes for data and output, respectively.
• Do not count quotation marks in your answer (same length as the longest sentence in a bullfight).
• The maximum output length is INT_MAX.

### Input:
You are given a string data and a function. The data is a word and the function should return the number of moves required to get to the next word, placing the end of the word on the first index.

The amount of words in the string is divisible by 2.

For example, "SPERN", PALANT" yields a two words in Spern palant".

"SPERN PALANT"

(Hard) Spells: Spells are any words you add to your spellbook that don't come with experience requirements to learn them and/or create magical effects. However, they can increase the duration you are fireproof by multiplying your fireproof duration by two, but they can't be cast in combat. The more you use a spell, the more you learn about it and better you can use it when it is cast.

How to use:

• Travel to a temple and purchase the needed supply via robbing the corpse(s).
• Decide on the name of the spell using a random generator.
• Spells with a star behind them (*) can combine two or more spells to create a new spell. Spells of the same name but of different stars will no longer add up the two or more spells and will instead only add up the amount of knowledge of them that you have.
• You can use up to 5 spells currently in your possession, as well as add spells from dragon chests that are found on your adventures. If you have no spells in your possession, you can only add a spell from a dragon chest.
• Spells can't be cast repeatedly if you are doing other spells at the same time. Spells can go on for up to 1 minute without addition of anything else.

Input: Your pokemon, your deck, your hand, your field, your opponent's pokemon, your opponent's deck, your opponent's hand, your opponent's field, the date, all cards on the field

Your goal is to win the game much like in many realtime rpgs. Pokémon quiz games have a generically enforced ending, but a standard video game doesn't.

In a standard video game (Uber), you are not limited to a 6-card deck, and you don't have a hand of cards; you have a 200 card set of cards that you continually shuffle through during battle. In reality, Pokémon games work based off of a number of points per turn, where you both collect energy to potentially, later in game, use an Item, Pokémon, or other Special Card to make your Pokémon's energy count and therefore attack count even higher.

If cards were the equivalent of Pokémon, then determining which Pokémon you have chosen within 1-5 would be a deck builder skill - but nobody in reality knows exactly what Pokémon they have.

In the next game (Vestibule), Pokémon are contained within gyms. The defender of the gym first decides on which Pokémon to send out. Then the non-defending Pokémon player decides which of their own Pokémon to send out for battle. In this game, on each turn, the Pokémon is only shuffled and then 're-shuffled' (used a letter) before it's sent back to the deck and is re-shuffled.

The reason that I will use Vestibule to showcase a Pokémon game is because it is based off of card pool size 100, while not allowing players to play only a 'mon' or a'dex'-ed Pokémon. This would add an additional element of confusion in the card drawing process. Calculate card pool replacement size of decks, hands, and field(s) only, not pool replacement for Pokémon played onto field - those are Pokémon. You can use facts associated with Pokémon card pools to make your job significantly easier (whether it be an online simulator, a premade deck, etc.) Pokémon game-related rules can be found here.

In respect to computing capabilities/physics, you are allowed to anticipate 25 dex+# number of cards, although at lower dexes your mental abilities will be drastically effected and you will be forced to anticipate the chance factors at your respective dex.

The rules of this game can be changed, but it must be loosely based off of one of the following:

• Rotation - a modified Pokémon TCG deck

• Generations - a randomly generated pull of drafted/premade deck which you then must build towards

• Masters - the original, unmodified Pokémon TCG deck

• Vestibule - a modified TCG deck in which Pokémon go back and forth from deck to field

or the obvious Pokémon Quiz game.
